text_blocks.text: We'll hear argument now in Number oh oh ten eighty-nine, Toyota Motor Manufacturing versus Ella Williams.
Mr. Roberts.
[Inaudible]

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mister Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

The Sixth Circuit below held that the respondent, Ms. Williams, was substantially limited in performing manual tasks and therefore disabled under the Americans with Disabilities Act because she could not perform the manual tasks associated with her assembly line job, specifically gripping a sponge and repetitively wiping down cars with her arms at shoulder level for an extended period of time.
That test for disability status was wrong.
It was wrong because it is inconsistent with the statute which requires a substantial limitation on a major life activity.

Repetitively wiping down cars with arms at shoulder level for an extended period of time is not a major life activity, and being limited in that activity does not constitute being substantially limited in the major life activity of performing manual tasks in general.
A plaintiff must show a substantial limitation in a broad range of manual tasks to meet the statutory standard.

The most that the court of appeals could extrapolate was that Ms. Williams was substantially limited in the tasks associated with jobs that required gripping tools and repetitive activity with arms at shoulder level for an extended period of time.
That is a specialized and idiosyncratic limitation.
It is not a substantial...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: limitation...
Mr. Roberts,

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: can I just ask if at at the outset, so you have plenty of time to comment on there's expert testimony, as I read the briefs, that on your opponent's side that she's suffers a lack of access to the labor market from fifty to fifty-five percent of the jobs, both nationwide and in Kentucky.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: A a number of things about that.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: When you say it was rejected by the district court, you don't mean it was inadmissible.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The the district court considered it and said it was not probative of what it purported to show, a loss of access to the job market.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Roberts, in the same vein as Justice Stevens' question, how does the worker's compensation notion of disability fit in? As I understand it, she was assessed as having a twenty percent what was it partial disability for worker's compensation purposes.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: B- but but pursuant to very different standards.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why wouldn't twenty percent limitation twenty percent occupational impairment be a substantial limitation?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, first of all, it may be pertinent if the standards were the same, but only under the working category.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Why why did the court of appeals avoid addressing the work approach? It was it because it thought this Court had rejected that?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, a couple of reasons.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Should we address that, or because it was not addressed below, leave that alone?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I think the the more typical approach would be not to address the major life activity of working since it was not addressed below, except to this extent.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: The test is circular.
Well in in looking at a substantial limitation, do we focus on the things that the person cannot do or the things they still can do or both?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: What do we do?
C- Certainly with respect to manual tasks, you have to look at both because it's not enough, obviously, to say there's one particular manual task that I can't do.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: She...

Roberts, may I just stop you on something you just said? I thought the Sixth Circuit said in its opinion that it had considered recreation, household chores, living generally, as well as the work-related impairments.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: A a very important sentence that I think has to be read carefully.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's  You can...
assume that, though, in some cases, couldn't you?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I mean  it...
You're not you do- if suppose a person says I cannot be a watchmaker and the reason he can't is he's blind.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Certainly.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Even though he only mentioned watchmaking.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Certainly.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: All right.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: But it's it's really the disability that we're focusing on, and in the circumstances someone like that would be able not only not to perform the job but also not to do the things that the judge said below, a reasonable inference from the nature of the disability.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: First, because that type of an inference is contradicted by the record.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: activity.
that's what I w- w- my until you said the last part, my thought was, well, we need a trial on this.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Oh, no because...

serious is this disability? What d- is does it disqualify her from doing? But do we have to go on to categorize between whether it's working, gardening, what is a major life activity? I mean, isn't it just is this person hurt badly enough that there are an awful lot of things that she can't do?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, no.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: And both...
that's bothering me.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: this or that or the other thing,
or to use a more broad, general judgment, is this person incapable of doing a lot of things that people do in life.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, first of all, with respect to working, it is important I think to identify what major life activity you're talking about because as the EEOC has recognized in its regulations, as this Court has indicated, there are all sorts of problems when you say working is a major life activity.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Roberts, can I just interrupt again? I you've explained why the fifty percent figure is is wrong.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Of yes, you can, and I and certainly in a manual tasks case, you can submit evidence and say, here's an example of manual tasks that I can't perform, the ones that are required at work.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Did it is it is it your view that by including the non-work im- impairment that she has, you sort of increase the universe of things she has to she you compare it to, and therefore, the there's a smaller percentage of an impairment, and therefore, it's not substantial?

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

is I'm limited in manual tasks, you do have to look, and this is what all the other courts of appeals have done, the broad range of manual tasks.

overriding sin, that was it, wasn't it? Instead of considering a range of jobs I'm sorry a class of jobs...

just jobs.

text_blocks.text: The- then it would seem to me to be properly analyzed as a working case.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Very well, Mr. Roberts.

roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: We agree that the Sixth Circuit applied an incorrect test in determining whether a person is substantially limited in the major life activity of performing manual tasks.
Ms. McDowell, I didn't think that the Sixth Circuit had said we're looking only at one job.

I I suppose it's perfectly obvious a person who can't raise their hands above heart level couldn't paint the ceiling at least.

of the analysis, if one --

the court of appeals...

and ability to perform.

text_blocks.text: Un- under the Longshore Harbor Workers and Compensation Act , we ru- the courts routinely look at what jobs are in the community that this person is eligible for after they've suffered an injury.

e- Yes.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States

on the major life activity.

text_blocks.text: Oh, certainly it would become a jury question in many cases.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The EEOC regs that you're referring to discuss the major life activity of working.
Yes, that wrecks it. I know. I know, but they're...
taking the wrong they're taking the wrong approach in your view.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I believe this route is consistent wit- with what the agency has said, specifically that one should consider working as a major life activity only if a plaintiff cannot satisfy any of the other major life activities, including performing manual tasks.
May I ask you one question? Is it relevant that she may not be able to perform a lot of jobs she never performed? For example, is it relevant that she couldn't be a roofer, for example?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It may or may not, and I'm not sure that we have a position on that at this point, Justice Stevens.
The mere fact that she hadn't done it --
her employment history and that's the only possible thing we look at in determining whether her working ability has been impaired.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, I don't think you look only at the...
plaintiff's working history.
then that she couldn't be a roofer, electrician, or a painter or a lot of other things.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: It may bell [: well] well be relevant.
To what extent do we...

take account of the particular individual? For example, for someone who is making a high income as a corporate executive, it wouldn't matter that she couldn't vacuum the rug because she's has paid someone else to do that for many years.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: May I answer, Your Honor? In focusing on a major life activity of manual tasks, we would suggest looking at the generalized person.
Thank you.

roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court: This case is not about the inability to perform a single job.
Mr. Rosenbaum, so far as the question presented here is, do you are you would defend the Sixth Circuit's opinion?

text_blocks.text: I defend the result, Mr. Chief Justice.

text_blocks.text: I disagree when the Sixth Circuit says that after you determine an individual is substantially limited, you must go farther and that individual must show that their limitation affects their work.

Otherwise you could have answered my question no.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: You you --

an individualized determination because the most severe case of carpal tunnel syndrome could qualify as rendering that person a disabled person within the meaning of this this specialized legislation.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That's right because the regulations say is that if they're significantly restricted concerning the condition, the manner, or the duration of the activity, then they are substantially disabled.
has trouble --

have any notion of what percentage of the population would be taken in if we use the standard n- the class that she was put in for worker's compensation purposes, t- a twenty percent occupational impairment how many people?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: I c- I have no figures that would relate that to the population as a whole.

Is there anything that suggests that those people, the people who are in a sense not the most disabled, but the people who are not quite in that category are the ones who are really discriminated against?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: S-
Because the ones who can't work at all, obviously, are not discriminated against.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, I I'm not sure that I can explain all of its ramifications, but I can say that there was certainly a concern that people who were labeled disabled would be stereotyped and that employers would be hesitant to give them the same vocational opportunities as non-disabled people would be, even though the disability had no effect on the job.

Well that one one of the problems with this is w- we're looking at the entry classification, disability, but on the facts of this case, she was able to do a job if the employer sliced it a certain way.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: That issue is not reached in this case.

I I know that we we don't get to what is the how much accommodation would be required, but it's a little hard to to keep th- that from view because if the employer doesn't have would not have to make the accommodation that she's seeking, the- then this case is not very significant.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Well, let me let let me say a couple of things.

But the the employer decided to change what the workers do, and as I un- understand assembly lines, that's not uncommon to take people from doing the same thing every day, day in and day out, train them for several jobs, and then they rotate.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: In the Sixth Circuit, there's the case of Kiphart versus Saturn where that issue was put to the jury where the employer said, you've got to be able to rotate through all of the tasks in your group, and since you, the allegedly disabled person, were not able to, we're entitled to fire you.
but we say it wasn't.
standard d- of accommodation, is it?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Excuse me?
I- isn't essential isn't the standard, is it, that the employer has to show that it's essential that...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, no.
There are reasonableness considerations to accommodation.
these things.
don't you have to look at both in in trying to assess the extent of somebody's incapacity to do a major life activity? You co- you...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: inevitably...
it's not a defense to the ADA claim to say, look, they can do a lot of stuff.

Mr. Rosenbaum, co- could could you tell us what you want us to do? Assuming we agree with you, you want us to take the Sixth Circuit opinion as as be- as a as affirming a summary judgment for you on the disability portion.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Correct.
Now, let's assume we don't agree with you on on the point.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Not in total.
They --
that's that's what they...

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: say. I'm pre-
wondering why we can do that when the Sixth Circuit hasn't addressed the you know, the other areas of disability.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: The case is before the Court in the procedural posture of proceedings for a summary judgment.
It goes to a jury.
It goes to the jury.
Thank you, Mr. Rosenbaum.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you.
Mr. Roberts, you have two minutes remaining.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: What about the other the other two issues? I mean, the the the court of appeals did not purport to reach the working as a substantial life activity and what else? Lifting as a substantial life activity.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Can certainly reverse with respect to the summary judgment on performing manual tasks.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: So, you acknowledge we would have to remand for for its consideration of those.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: Unless the Court felt, given the fact that the issues with respect to working were insinuated into the case by the Sixth Circuit's approach, that it was appropriate to address that major life activity as well.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Even as to manual tasks, are you asking for a a ruling in your favor on summary judgment on that, or are you saying it shouldn't have been e- effectively summary judgment for the plaintiff and then we go to the next stage, that that it could be a jury question o- on manual tasks?

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

text_blocks.text: No, no.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

text_blocks.text: Thank you, Mr. Roberts.

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Associate Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States

roles.institution_name: Supreme Court of the United States
roles.role_title: Chief Justice of the United States

transcript.title: Toyota Manufacturing, Kentucky, Inc. v. Williams
